text: Frangois comes out of the café. Across the street, we discover a large building whose slightly outdated fagade is not particularly welcoming. He walks over to the imposing entrance that bears the shield of the City of Paris in wrought iron and beneath which we read “JAURES MIDDLE SCHOOL”. On the opposite sidewalk, coming from the other end of the street, a small group of teachers hurries towards the entrance. Frangois hears them joking.
He’s a really great guy, not the back- slapping type but... Frangois greets them in passing.

We discover the school’s deserted corridors. Through the doorway of a classroom, Frangois sees a few cleaners who, in a very calm atmosphere, clean the tables and line them up neatly, wash the windows.. A short distance further on a man in overalls applies one last coat of paint to an administrative notice board.
Around the principal in the meeting room, the teachers, old or new, introduce themselves briefly, as in a casting session.
Hello, everybody, I'm Hervé. I’ve been at the school three years now. I teach sports. I’d like to welcome all our new colleagues. The students can be tough but they're good kids. There you go.
Hello, everybody, I'm Olivier. I teach physical science and I've been here for 4 years.
I'm Patrick and I teach multiplication tables, and occasionally mathematics! I've been at this school for a number of years.
Hello, I'm Anne. I used to work in the Lyon suburbs, in Bron to be precise, and I teach English. I'm looking for my new colleagues. Hello...
Hello, I’m Isabelle...
Pleased to meet you. Hello...
I’m Christiane...
I'm Frédéric, I teach history and geography and I used to work out in the suburbs of Paris, in Aulnay-sous-Bois if anyone knows it. I'm happy to be in the city now.
Hello, I'm Julie, the year supervisor. I'd like to welcome you all and wish you a good year.
Hello, I'm Aline, I'm the cook and I'd like to welcome you all.
Thank you, Aline.
Hello, everyone. I'm Gilles, I've been teaching mathematics for many years now. I'm retiring at the end of this year. I'd like to wish the new arrivals plenty of courage.
I'm Frangois. I teach French and I'm starting my fourth year here. Welcome, everybody. Then the principal hands out the timetables, eliciting a few sighs of satisfaction or disappointment.
In the staff room, a new arrival listens to the succinct comments of an older member of staff, OLIVIER, on the different students in a second-year class as he runs through a list.

Nice, nice, not nice, not nice at all... He's nice, not nice, watch him, not nice at all, nice, not nice, she's not nice at all. INT. CLASS —- DAY The children noisily enter the glass as Frangois looks on. The students take their places in general confusion, the girls on one side, the boys on the other. They show each other their new gear: pencil cases, brand-name exercise books.. Frangois, clearly used to this kind of agitation, raises his voice.

All right, all right, all right! Hey, hey, hey! Calm down now! Stop stirring things up there and remove your hood, please. You two back there, there's a place here. One of you comes up front. Things start to calm down.

Right, let's get one thing clear from the word go.. Hey! I want to get this clear from the start. We waste five minutes lining up outside, five coming up, five settling down: fifteen minutes out of an hour. Do you realize what fifteen lost minutes means? With twenty-five hours a week and thirty weeks in the year, we lose thousands of minutes. In other schools, they do a full hour. Imagine how far ahead they get in a year. Figure it out!  KHOUMBA, a girl with long hair in the style of Diana Ross, speaks up without raising her hand first.
We never do an hour!
Put your hand up to speak. What is it?
We never do an hour. You always say that.
What do you mean, “we never do an hour”?
Teachers say we do an hour's class but we never do.
Yes.
We never do an hour's class. We start at 8.30 and finish at 9.25. That doesn't make an hour.
All right, it's fifty-five minutes. Thanks, that's an important point.
But we never do an hour. Stop saying other schools do an hour. They don't either.

All right, all I'm saying is that we waste time. Like right now. To start with, take out a sheet of paper, fold it in two so that it can stand on the edge of your desk clearly and, using block capitals, write your full name on it. While BOUBACAR sluggishly obeys, WEY, in the front row, translates the instructions into Chinese for his neighbor and shows her how to do it. A few rows behind them, ESMERALDA, Khoumba’s friend and neighbor, butts in.
Why do we have to write our names?
So I can get to know who you are.
But you know us!
We had you last year.
Esmeralda, I don't know if you've noticed, but half of the kids here are new. So it can help. Be happy. This way, people will know your name.
I'm not doing it.
Cut it out.
I won't if you don't.
Ah, you have a point. For those of you who don't know me, I'm Mr. Marin.
Ms. Marin.
Hey, are you a marine?
He wiped you out, that’s wicked.
Very funny.
He didn’t wipe you out, he busted you.
Come on, it shouldn't take so long. You should be a lot quicker. Five minutes to write a name. That's ridiculous!
SOPHIE, in passing, offers a biscuit to RACHEL and Frangois who is sitting nearby.
A biscuit for the first day?
I'm okay, thanks.
I wouldn’t mind one.
Rachel, a biscuit will buck you up.
Thanks. INT. CLASS —- DAY On the board, Frangois writes the words that the students haven't understood in the text that they are studying. A slightly affected student raises his hand.
All right... "Witty". That's a word we'll try to explain later. Are there any other words in the text that you don't understand? Burak.
The word "condescension". Frangois notes the word on the board, just under other more or less complicated words. He turns to the class.
The word "condescension", yes, that's a complicated word. Do you have any idea, Burak, what that might mean? Any idea at all?
A vague idea but I'm not sure.
You're not sure? All right, we'll talk about that later then. Yes, Damien?
"Argentite".
Argentite. What does that mean?
It's people who live in Argentina.
Right, exactly, the inhabitants of Argentina.
Wow, what a moron! Wicked!
Argentites and Argentitesses.. No, of course not. Damien, who lives in Argentina?
The Argentites.
No, you know that's not right, you watch soccer on TV. Argentina's players are called...
Footballers.
Oh, what a big kid! A discreet-looking student raises her hand.
Let's move on. Any other difficult words in this text? Henriette? Is there anything that you didn't understand? I imagine there is.
“Henceforth”.

"Henceforth". Thanks for the prompt, Samantha. All right! I think that will do. Let's take a look at these words. All right. "Austrian".. Wey was the one who picked the word "Austrian". Yes, Esmeralda.
I mean, we all know what "Austrian" is. People from Austria.
Okay, but Wey doesn't know and, well, Austrian isn't really...
Maybe, but he's the only one, everyone else knows!
Okay, we get the message. You didn't know "misleading", so you're not really in any position to talk about all that. We agree on that?
Yes, but everyone knows what "Austrian" means! It's easy.

Look here, nobody's perfect. Besides, "Austrian" is not a very important word. It refers to someone from the land of Austria, which is a pretty tiny country. We can live without the word. For example, can anyone name a famous Austrian? Not one hand is raised.
Mozart. “Wolfang” Amadeus Mozart.
What do you call him?
“Wolfang” Amadeus Mozart.

He could have been "Wolfang" maybe if he were English, not Austrian. Mozart was Austrian, yes, but do you know any other famous Austrians? So, basically, Austria could vanish from the map and no one would notice. But, seriously, it's a country south of Germany. So check a map, Wey. You'll see where it is. Souleymane, can you note the words too, like everyone else? Frangois’ blatant insincerity inspires a few collusive smiles in the class. Wey is delighted to have understood that his teacher is joking.
I forgot my things.
And no one can lend you some paper so you can do it?
No, it’s okay, I'll do it at home.
You'll do it at home. Sure you will. That's your approach. Not a stroke of work in class and everything done at home.

I'm serious. Don’t worry, it’1l be okay, it’1l be okay... Thanks. Souleymane, convinced that he has had the last word, seems fairly pleased with himself. Frangois turns to the list of words on the board again.
All right, let's move on to "succulent". "Succulent" is a word that we'll try to guess the meaning of. What's in "succulent"? Suck...
Suck off!
Jerk.
Very funny, Boubacar. Very witty indeed.
He should be sent out for that, sir.

I'll give you a sentence with "succulent". Bill enjoys a succulent cheeseburger. On either side of the word on the board, he writes a sentence: “Bill enjoys a succulent cheeseburger.” And he underlines the word “succulent”. A voice speaks out behind him.
Cheeseburgers are crap, they stink.
Who said that?  10.
Cheeseburgers are the best.
I said it. Why a cheeseburger?
Well, since you say they stink, that means you think cheeseburgers aren't succulent.
I don’t care, but cheeseburgers are crap.
All right, but what I mean is, what I just said about cheeseburgers should have made the penny drop. Those who know become more and more impatient.
Sir, sir, what does that mean?
What does what mean?
The penny thing...
"To make the penny drop." That should make the penny drop. No one knows the expression?
A clue.

That's it. If the penny drops, it means you're given a clue. When I say if Cherif thinks cheeseburgers stink, it means he doesn't think they're succulent, that should help you see what "succulent" means.
What's with the Bills?
What bills?
Not bills, the name Bill.  11.
Bill and Ben.
You always use weird names. Why don’t you use...
It's not a weird name. A recent US President was called Bill, remember.
Why don't you use Aissata or Rachid or Ahmed or...
You always use whitey names. It’s wicked.
What names?
Honky names.
What's a honky?
Honkies, Frenchies, frogs. Frangois seems a little put out, as if he had been trying to avoid this kind of discussion.
You're not French, Esmeralda?
No, I'm not French.
Really? I didn't know.
Well, I am French, but I’m not proud of it.
Fine, I'm not either, actually.
Wiped him out!  12.
Neither am I, in fact, I’m not proud to be French either.
Why do you use these names then?
Khoumba, if I start choosing names to suit your different ethnic origins, it'll never end.
But change them a bit..
Yeah, Bill, Ben, Bob..
Change them a bit.
So what do you suggest?
Er, Aissata...
Mamadou, Bintou...
Fatou. No, Aissata. Aissata!
In the depths of his locker, Frangois finds a mandarin orange that seems to have been there for some time. Frédéric comes to sit down next to Frangois, a coffee in his hand.
Excuse me. Do you have class 4/3 in French?
Yes, I'm the class supervisor too.
Do you already know what book you'll be reading?  13.
No, I haven't decided yet.
Because in history, I'll be starting with the Ancien Régime. If you want to link into that, what kind of books are there?
Well, there's the Enlightenment but that’s tough for them in their year.
How about Voltaire? Is he tough?
Well, he's not easy.
I don't know. "Candide" is an easy read...
Not in their year.
“Zadig"..

Yes, maybe, but it’d be tough. INT. CLASS —- DAY Frangois has bags under his eyes and seems to be having a bad day. Behind him, on the board, a verb is conjugated in the imperfect tense. The verb endings have been underlined. The whole class, silent, works on an exercise. Frangois seems to be miles away. His weary gaze sweeps over the class. All of a sudden, he speaks.
Okay, in 20 seconds, we correct it.

No, sir, please! We haven't finished. With some sweeping gestures, DALLA asks Rabah, in the opposite row, for the time. Rabah starts to reply with equally exaggerated gestures. Frangois seems to snap out of his daze and answers curtly.  14.

We can't spend two hours on the imperfect. Dalla, you can ask me for the time if you want. With an involuntary wink, she signals to NASSIM whose pen has leaked over his jacket. Frangois, on discovering the scene, raises his eyes to the heavens in exasperation.
Sir, this crap pen keeps leaking! It's getting on my nerves.
Who has a handkerchief for.. Rabah takes a tissue out of his pocket and stands to take it to Nassim.
Me!
Rabah, Rabah... Ask before you stand, okay. Rabah sits back down.
May I? In passing, Rabah trips over his neighbor's bag and stops himself from falling by grabbing Juliette’s shoulder, sprawling over her exaggeratedly. She pushes him away roughly.
Yes. Gently, okay.
The perv! He touched her tits! The perv!
Come on, just give him the handkerchief! Boubacar, spare us your comments.
Goddam pedophile! You big kid!
Sir, sir.
Okay, okay... Quiet!  15.
You ain’t got a chick or what? You need to press up against chicks, Rabah!
Hey, take it easy! Only Esmeralda doesn’t burst out laughing. She seems bothered by something. As she thinks, she ends up asking her question.
(to Esmeralda) Yes...
Sir, why do they say the imperfect indicative?
If you want chicks, let me know, I’11l give you contacts. Frangois seems happy that Esmeralda is so motivated. He speaks to her with gentleness.
Quiet, Souleymane! All right, Esmeralda, why the indicative? She raises her eyes to the heavens.
You're pushing it! If I knew, I wouldn't ask!
I can imagine. How about the others? Does anyone know why we specify the imperfect indicative? Why not just the imperfect? Nassim.
Do you mind if I go wash my hands because...
Go on, wash them and get it over with.
He’s gonna visit the corridors.
Make it quick!  16.
He'll be back in a week! I’m going with him!
All right, enough! If we talk specifically about the imperfect indicative, that means it's different than another imperfect. Which imperfect is that? Agam? AGAM answers calmly.
The imperfect subjunctive.
Exactly. The imperfect subjunctive. Can anyone give me an example of the imperfect subjunctive? I don't believe it, Khoumba, go on.
Hold on, I may be wrong... Frangois gives her an encouraging smile.
Yes, I think so too.
I were.
I were. Of course, from the verb "to werr"?
No, I were.. I don’t know.
I wuz.
No, I were, you were, you were, they were...
All right. That's not bad but you use it wrongly. You vaguely recall the imperfect subjunctive. Imagine I say: "He insists that I be" - let's say - "in shape." What is "be" in that example? Eva?  17.
The present subjunctive.
Very good. For the imperfect subjunctive, we follow the sequence of tenses and use a past: "He insisted..."
He insisted... he insisted that I be.
"He insisted that I..." Khoumba?
Were.
Were, yes!
You really think I'll tell my mom. "He insisted that I were'd been in shape?" And that she'll understand?
Not "I were'd been". Learn to use it before you start complaining.
He insisted that I were'd been in shape.
"That I were in shape". Use the sequence of tenses.
But no one says that in real life, it's true, it's true!
I was right! "I were"!
All right, will you let me answer the question that you asked me? If you care.
Yes, you may.  18.
The first thing I notice is, before mastering something, the imperfect subjunctive, you're already telling me it's no use. Start by mastering it, then you can call its use into question.
Sir, why are you criticizing us?
What?
They're right, it's not the way people talk now, that's the way they talked in the old days. Even my gran didn't say that.
Or your great granddad. It's from the Middle Ages!
No, it’s not from the Middle Ages and for starters
It is!
Of course it is!
It's bourgeois.
Tell me, when was the last time you heard someone talk like that? When was the last time you heard someone talk like that?
Yesterday, with friends, we used the imperfect subjunctive... (he is briefly interrupted by jeers) All right, all right.. Can I reply?
Yep!  19.

I'm ready to talk this over, but calmly. All right, it's true not everyone talks that way. In fact, people who do are pretty rare, I'll grant you that. I'd even say only snobs use the imperfect subjunctive.
What's a snob?

Snobs are slightly affected, slightly precious people who tend to put on airs. He makes an precious gesture with his wrist. A student’s voice rises up from the back of the class, convinced that he has found the answer.
Homosexuals? This remark makes Frangois smile.

No, not homosexuals. You can be affected and refined without being homosexual, Boubacar. In any case, what I see is that this register may seem formal and a bit affected and even bourgeois. But the important fact is these different registers exist as I keep telling you, and as I shall carry on telling you, I think. You need to be able to use them all: familiar, current, formal, oral and written Move between them and use them all. Yes, Lucie?
How do we know what's for written and what's for oral?
Why is a word more for one register than the other? Normally, that's something that you pick up as you go along. You need to use intuition.
What’s intuition?  20.
Intuition is when you can't use thinking. When you can't really... It's not knowing but more like sensing something. That's it. Intuition is when you sense things.
What if you don't sense them?
If you don't sense them, well... You gain intuition by using the language. That's when you learn to distinguish almost automatically between oral and written styles.
Sir, Souleymane wants to say something.
Shut your mouth! Shut it!
What does Souleymane want to say?
But... please... okay... say it!
What is it? What? Calm down!
If he says it, you'll tell.
Cut it out! No fighting!
I'll whop you!
Go ahead, bro, just quit playing the tough guy! Frangois is surprised to see Souleymane, who has been talking with his neighbor for the last few minutes, with his hand raised.
Souleymane, what's wrong?
I’1l whop you one!  21.
Boubacar, turn round. Boubacar, turn round. What is it, Souleymane?
Nothing. Boubacar, who seems to know what his friend’s question is, takes over from him.
Say it, bro.
Apparently something is up.
Don't send him to the principal if he says it.
If I tell you, I'm good for Guantanamo! Frangois takes an obvious pleasure in pushing Souleymane who, himself, is having fun upping the stakes.
No, no.
(as one) Guantanamo, Guantanamo, Guantanamo!
Forget it, I'll be tased.
No, you won't be "tased", as you put it.
No, no, no.
What is it? You have a question?
Yep.
So ask it.
It's too wicked. It's too wicked!  22.
No, it’s not too wicked.
But it's the pits for you.
Look, now we've come to this, just ask it!
I have your word?
Hurry it up!
I don't know.. This is what I heard, okay? I didn't say it but I heard... People say you like men. I didn't say it!
Who says that?
Well, just people, see..
Really?
They say Mr. Marin likes men and all that. Different reactions in the class. We hear laughter and cries of surprise. Frangois smiles as if he had been expecting this question sooner or later.
Okay. So others say that, not you?
No...
No, you’re not interested? Souleymane squirms on his chair, smiling awkwardly.
No, I don’t give a damn.
So why ask the question then?  23.
It’s for the others. I'm a spokesman.
But the question doesn’t interest you at all?
I don't give a damn. If you like men, fine.
Exactly! Unwilling to back down now that he has come this far and perhaps basking in the prestige that he is acquiring with the rest of the class, Souleymane insists:
So is it true or not?
So you are asking me!
Homosexual isn't an insult, sir. It isn’t an insult.
You say it isn't but it seems to be a problem for you. You find it odd, men liking other men.
Maybe it is, I don't know. But is it true or not?
No, it's not. Feel better now?
Yeah? Sure.
Sorry to disappoint you. That’s how it is. Souleymane simply pouts dubiously.
Wiped him out big time!  24.
All right, if Souleymane doesn't mind, now he's settled his hang-ups, let's get back to the imperfect indicative.
From a high angle, we see the students horsing around during the break. Souleymane is taking photos with his cell phone.
Change the pose, change the pose! Yeah, like that! Not bad. Go on, move. Hey, what are you doing?
Cut it out, please!
What’s up? Who asked you? Look at your mug!
Hey, give me a break, it’s fucking okay! Take these jerks, then we'll see.
Go on, show me your backs. Yeah, one more, go on.
Wow, that’s a classy display.
You bet!
Got one for me?
You can't afford it.
How much is it?
Too much.

Stop thinking I'm broke like you.  25. INT. CLASS —- DAY Justine comes up to the board, looking a little worried. Her classmates stare at her as if she were climbing the gallows. She hesitates for a second but then picks up the chalk and takes the plunge. She starts declining a verb, making a mess of it, then hurriedly erases the word that she has just written. The suspense is perceptible. Justine ends up turning to Frangois.
Hold on, that’s not it.
She screwed up there. She thinks it's a regular verb.
No, the verb's "swim". Swimmed.
Quiet!
I swimmed.
Justine... Swummed!
Justine, work it out yourself.
Swammed!
Swummed. That's better, it mixes the two!
It’s swammed, it’s swammed!
That’s not it!
It is!
She put swemmed.
Shut up! Swammed is...  26.
Try swommed!
All right, thank you, you can sit down.
You big kid! Swommed!
Let's see...
She can't write!
She can't write? Can you, Rabah?
You bet!
Go on then. Conjugate it properly. Correct her.
First, swimmed.
No, carry on. Cut it out, the rest of you!
Swammed.
Wrong again.
He sucks.
Just kidding. That's not what it is. It's not like that.
So what is it?
S.W.. Without an "I".  27.
Right, no "I". Why make fun of Justine, when you can't do any better than she can?
I can.
At least Justine got off to a good start... (to the rest of the class) That's enough now!
What’s up, sir?
Can I explain something to you?
It’s swammed.

What I'm seeing here, is that you can't focus for more than 20 seconds, like 3- year-olds. People aged 13, 14 or 15 like you're supposed to be.. If I ask a question, they should answer fast and then we waste no more time.
Your kidding around goes too far!
Not at all, I don’t think I go too far.
Everyone thinks you go too far. Sorry but...
I think so too!
Just a second, Khoumba. Everyone thinks so or only you think so?
No, everyone!
Speak for yourself for once.  28.
Everyone thinks so and I think you push it too, I mean, what is this?
I’m ready to cut you some slack and leave you right where you are...
Teach is spitting hate!
«but you'll never get anywhere!
That’s no reason to push it too far! That’s no reason to push it too far!
It is. That’s exactly why, the reason I just gave you.
Vincent bursts into the staff room that is particularly calm today. He sits down and starts to complain.

I'm sick of these clowns! Sick of them! I can't take any more! They're nothing, they know nothing, they look right through you when you try to teach them. They can stay in their shit! I'm not going to help them. They're so basic, so insincere, always looking for trouble. Go ahead, guys. Stay in your crap neighborhood. You'll be here all your lives and it serves you damn well right! I'll see the principal and tell him I'm not working with 3/2 again. No more technology for the rest of the year. Too bad. It's been three months now and they haven't done a single thing! Have you seen them in the yard? It's like they're in heat! They're all over each other like animals. It's crazy! It's the same in class. Kevin spent a whole hour going... "duh, duh, duh." I've never seen the like of it in 5 years. Enough! No more. We're not animals. Sorry, I'm. It's dumb.

Come on. Let's get some air.  29. INT. CLASS —- DAY It’s cold outside. The students, in their winter clothing, seem very excitable. On their desks, we see “The Diary of Anne Frank”. Some of them read the first few pages of it amid the general hubbub.

One extract isn't a lot to read for today. No one did it? We're wasting a crazy amount of time here. Okay, let's read it or reread it then. Who wants to read? Great.. Excellent work atmosphere today! Khoumba, go on.
I‘m not reading!
What do you mean, you’re not reading?
I don’t want to read.
So the class revolves around your desires now?
I don't want to read!
I don’t care if you don’t want to read! Khoumba’s sole reply is a sneering sound that immediately annoys Frangois. He addresses the other twenty-four students as witnesses.
What did Khoumba just do? Wey?
Sneer.
No, I meant her attitude. What did she show? They all think hard.
Insolence.  30.
Yes, that's right, you're an expert.
You're standing there, all angrulo with me! What is this?
I'm not, that's not true. And try saying it in French. What am I?
“Angrulo".
Say it in everyday French, please.
You're wired at me.
That's normal French?
You've got it in for me! Frangois is clearly spoiling for a fight and doesn’t want to leave it at this.
Not at all, I just want you to read. And I think I have the right to ask you to read, don't I?
No.
You don't think so?
No. No one has read it and you're picking on me! What is this?
Not at all, I’m not picking on you. I want to work and I've chosen you...
Yeah, sure, give me a break.
And I have the right to as your French teacher.  31.
Just drop it, I said! Drop it!
Shut up now! We’re listening!
Yeah, sure! No way, I’m not reading. You tell me to shut up, then to read. What is this?
What’s what?
Make your mind up! Think it through! Frangois has heard enough.
All right, you can come see me after class and we'll talk it over. It won't be fun.
Yeah, great!
You won't say that later. All right, Esmeralda, are you on strike too or can you read for us?
It's her life. I don’t give a damn.
Very good. In that case, will you read for us?
I'd be delighted to!
All right, Esmeralda, we're listening. While Esmeralda reads the extract, the other students listen more or less attentively. Khoumba, on the other hand, seems as furious as before.
"Dear Kitty, I'm known as a bundle of contradictions. As I've told you several times, my soul is split in two. (MORE)

On one side, my exuberant cheerfulness, my mocking approach to everything, my joy in life and my ability to take things lightly. By that, I mean not seeing any wrong in flirting, giving a kiss, embracing someone, or telling a tasteless joke. That side lies in wait, pushing back the other side which is more beautiful, purer and deeper. The truth is that no one knows Anne's better side and that's why most people can't stand me. I can be an amusing clown for an afternoon, but then everyone has had enough of me. So the nice Anne has never once been seen in company. But, in her loneliness, she always triumphs. My best to you. Anne Frank. Anne's diary ends here."

Anne Frank's diary ends here. Why? Because the police turned up at the rooms where Anne Frank's family was hiding and deported them all. Anne Frank died shortly after. That's what I asked earlier and what we've talked about several times already. When I read this, I learn about Anne Frank because she talks about herself and so I get to know her. When I ask you to write your own self-portraits, I'll expect the same. In other words, to learn things through your feelings. You can also talk about facts that will allow me to know you better. Yes, Lucie?
What we write won't be as gripping as... as what Anne Frank wrote. Our lives aren't as gripping.
All right... Juliette?
Well, someone aged 70 could talk about their life, but we have nothing to tell at 13.
I don't know, at 14, 15 or even 13, you've had experiences.  33.
Less than a man or a woman aged 70. They've lived a lot more, they're nearly through...
They have more to pass on.
It's funny. Basically, you don't think your lives are interesting.
I don't know, sir. What do we do? We just come to school, go home, eat and sleep.
Really? You come to school, eat, sleep. Fine. Okay, so the bare facts of your life are dull. But what you feel, Angelica, that's what's interesting.
But that's my business.
Yes, maybe, but I'm interested.
Yes, but you’re different.
Why am I different? I perfectly normal.
Because you're a teacher, that's why.
But this isn't the teacher talking.
It's your job.
You could say it's the human being.
Okay, but well... I think you're only saying that to get us to talk and stuff but it's not true.
Really? What isn't true?  34.
The fact that you're interested in knowing all that.
So you think I'm lying, that I'm not interested in you at all and that I'm pushing at this to convince you it's interesting?
No, it's not that but it's not as interesting as you say.
Maybe I am exaggerating a little. It's only natural since you don't agree with me. But, deep down, I'm totally sincere. Why is it such a problem for you to talk about your lives? Boubacar?
Well, there's stuff.. There's private stuff.
Yes, of course. What could be hard to say about your private lives? Burak?
Well, we may be ashamed to say certain things.
Yes, it has to do with shame. There are things you find it hard to say and even harder to write maybe.
Well, yes.
And... in your life, your personal life, when were you ashamed?
You can be ashamed of a pal's mom.
Ashamed of a pal's mom. Why? Because you find her ugly?  35.
No, it's not that. For instance, Rabah's mom. She offered me lunch at his place but I refused because I was ashamed.
You were ashamed to eat with Rabah's mother?
Yeah.
Because you think she’s unworthy of you?
No.
I don't understand. Tell me why, Boubacar.
I'm ashamed to eat in front of her because I respect her.
So, you never eat in front of people you respect?
No, it's not that. I mean, she's not my girlfriend!
So you can only eat in front of your girlfriend? Tell me why, Boubacar. I'm interested.
I can't explain it. In any case, I'm ashamed... I always hang out with Rabah, so I respect his mom. I don't eat in front of her, that's all.
So we'll know now that if Boubacar eats in front of us, it means he doesn't respect us.
No, it's not that! You can't understand. You can't understand.  36.
I can't understand, I'm not smart enough?
No, it's not that. You just can't understand.
Rabah.
The other week, I was at a party with nothing but Camemberters.
Nothing but Camemberters?
Yeah, like you.
Remind us what a Camemberter is.
Someone who stinks of cheese.
So you went to a party where everyone stank of cheese?
They were all in suits and ties. I was in my baggies and got these weird looks.
And you were ashamed?
Yeah. Because of the looks.
Basically, they were embarrassed in front of you and so you felt embarrassed in front of them.
No, they weren't embarrassed. They looked at me like I was an E.T.
I see.
But you are an E.T.!  37.
“Why's that Arab here?"
Okay, so it was a race thing or something...
I don't know.. I don't know. But the snacks were bacon-flavored.
So? Is that...
So I... abstained.
Right. Bacon, ham. Okay, I get it. Wey?
Young people these days have no shame.
Young people now?
Yes.
Like you, for instance?
Gimme a break! Drop your briefs!
You see, they have no shame. It's normal. Always normal.
Are you like them, Wey, or do you feel shame?
No, I’m not like them.
You feel shame from time to time?
Yes, shame for them.  38.
Shut your mouth! I'll waste your ugly mug! You should be ashamed, looking the way you do.
Hey! Hey! Anyone can speak but you stay polite, okay. So, Wey, why are you ashamed for them?
They have no shame. They yell, they hit each other. They make jokes, bother others. No shame.
But, Wey, aren't you confusing shame and discipline? You find the others rowdy and impolite?
It can be shameful, sir.
Yeah. Yeah, that can be shameful too.
All right.
You can be ashamed of your appearance.
Absolutely. You can be ashamed of your appearance. Tell me, Louise, are you ever ashamed of something physical?
My ears.
Your ears?
Can we see them?
You're ashamed of your ears? What's wrong with them?
They stick out.  39.

You think they stick out. Okay, well, I think that covers it all. You have all you need to figure it out. Take out your exercise books. Note the following exercise for next Thursday. It's very simple: "Write your self-portrait." Remember a self-portrait isn't an autobiography. I don't want your life story. Describe yourself and your personality. We'll read them in class and see how we can use them. Don't forget.
Goodbye, sir.
Goodbye. Hey, just a second, Khoumba! You know I want to see you. Give me your report book.
Why? Khoumba tosses the report book at him, which he doesn’t appreciate.
You know why. No, give it to me. Politely. That's enough now. Put your photo on it someday. Is it normal to refuse to read when a teacher asks you to? Is that normal?
There's others in the class!
Just because you're not the only one who screws up doesn't mean I can turn a blind eye to this. Does it?
Okay.
What happened this summer? What happened during the vacation?
I didn’t see you during the vacation.  40.

Yes, I know you didn't. That's why this is a problem for me. At the end of the year in June, we'd gotten on pretty well together. You participated in class. Since September, since the start of this year, you're not cooperative, you keep sulking, you refuse to read, etc, etc... What happened?
I just don't like reading anymore. Can you hurry, please?
No, I won't hurry! Explain. Why have things changed all of a sudden?
I can't stay a kid forever.
So it's a kid thing to cooperate? So that’s it.
I don’t like reading anymore.
Sure.
There's others in the class.
Of course, when you work, it's.. I'll give it back when I've finished. Okay?
But I’m in a hurry, my mom's waiting for me.
Maybe, but I want an apology first. An apology for what you did. "I apologize for being insolent, sir."
Sorry. Okay?
No, not "sorry". "I apologize for being insolent." Go ahead.  41.
I apologize for being insolent, sin...
No, "I apologize for being insolent." But be sincere. I want a real apology.
Can you hurry up, please? My mom's waiting. Maybe you have plenty of time...
Your mother can wait. She’s waiting for you to apologize. This is the ideal moment. I want a sincere apology that'1l stand for the rest of the year. We won't go on like this.
I apologize for being insolent to you.
More conviction!
Hey, come on.. I'm not saying it 50 times!
You two! What are you up to?
Nothing. We’re waiting.
Sure, sure...
May I?
Hurry, I'm listening!
I apologize for being insolent. May I go now, please? Thank you.
You joker!

Cut it out! Khoumba has spoken mechanically, with a total lack of conviction.  42. Frangois ends up handing her report book back. She takes it and skips over to the door. Just as she is about to vanish off along the corridor, she turns to Frangois and exclaims.
I didn't mean it.

You wiped him out big time! Way too wicked! Frangois leaps up from his desk but it’s too late. The girl has already vanished off along the corridor, to the giggles of her friends. Frangois kicks a chair in annoyance.

It’s night time. We are in the meeting room. The tables have been set out in a U-shape. Five or six teachers, a member of the school’s administration, parents’ representatives, two students (a boy and a girl from year four) are present.

Two weeks ago, at the last meeting, the teachers suggested introducing a penalty point system for the students based on the driving license system. If students broke a rule, they would lose points. As it's the teachers' idea, I'll let them speak.

Since last September, we've noticed an increase in problems within the school. Punishment has no effect on the students. So we had the idea of a penalty system. The students would have, for example, six points each and, depending on the misdeed, they'd lose one or two points. PARENTS’ REP #1 And when they run out of points?
When they get down to zero, they go before the disciplinary committee. PARENTS’ REP #2 As a parents' representative, this is typical of the school's bad habits. (MORE)
PARENTS’ REP #2 (CONT'D) You always condemn the students but never praise them.

But they earn praise on their own. They do it with their grades, by moving up a class and we do it in staff meetings by encouraging them to work if their grades are below average. Then there's the honor roll, the congratulations... That all counts! BURAK’S MOTHER In your system, you take away points for misdeeds but why not go further and give points to those who do good things?
Like gold stars!
I'm all for praising the students but if students collect points and end up with 34 points, say, that leaves room for all kinds of trouble we can't control.

Without going as far as these imaginary 34 points, six points to start with means they can cause trouble without punishment. I'm sorry, but losing a point or two isn't a real punishment. It can create a dangerous sense of impunity. For me, the idea's totally wrong-headed.
In that case, we could find a punishment where the students lose all their points in one go. But why bother with the points in that case?
That’s the whole problem.
It’s not simple.
You know, what you call a sense of impunity gives us room to maneuver. When you're dealing with punishments that are cut and dried, you can't adapt them to each case.
No, I don't agree. The rules apply in the same way to all the students. They break them, they're punished. If not, why bother with rules?

Maybe, but dealing with extremely strict rules creates the greatest tension. Take cell phones, for instance. We agreed on a rule that cell phones were not allowed in class. Well, sorry, but I break that rule because I realized it wasn't a problem for me. There's room to maneuver, to be tolerant.
Sure, that's the reign of the arbitrary.
No, the law and the spirit of the law.

Now then, I know we could talk all night but that's not possible. We have other topics to tackle. In particular, one vital issue, a very sensitive one, concerning the coffee machine that the teachers have asked to talk about.

It's a sensitive issue, all right! Everyone agrees there's a real problem with the coffee machine this year. The price of a coffee has gone up from 40 centimes to 50 centimes. That may seem petty but since we drink several coffees a day at 8, at 10 or at 4 in the afternoon, it works out at a lot. So we've clubbed together to buy a coffee maker. That way, we can drink as much coffee as we want without having to count.
Monsieur Pierre will be delighted to reply. Monsieur Pierre, the bursar, starts speaking shyly. All the same, we can tell that nothing will stop him.  45.

Yes. First of all, I'd like to remind you that this machine was installed in 2001 to replace a machine that needed the intervention of an outside company for restocking, repairs, etc. It was very expensive and not at all profitable. We switched to the new machine which isn't profitable yet.
I'm sorry to hear that! Used to the bursar’s endless speeches, the people present exchange embarrassed looks that Monsieur Pierre, his eyes glued to his notes, haughtily ignores.
And so we increased the price of coffee by ten centimes to fifty centimes. There. The thing has to be economically viable.
Isn't anyone shocked by this?
It's clear and logical to me.
Gathered around a meager buffet, all the people attending the meeting sip champagne. Frangois quickly slips out to smoke a cigarette in the yard.
We find Frangois alone, walking down a long, dark corridor as the sounds of the small party fade.

He pushes open the door of the staff room. Two CLEANING WOMEN who were chatting peacefully pick up their gear and apologize. Frangois tells them that they can stay, but the two women have already slipped out into the corridor. Frangois opens his locker and pulls out a pile of papers on which the mandarin orange is balanced. Frangois puts the fruit back in the depths of the locker and automatically sniffs the first sheet before reading it. It’s the work that he gave Khoumba as punishment.  46. We can just make out the title, written in block capitals: “RESPECT”.

"Respect." #Adolescents learn to respect their teachers little by little because of their threats or the fear of having problems. For starters, I respect you and respect must be mutual. For instance, I don't say you're hysterical, so why do you say I am? I've always respected you so I don't understand why I have to write this. In any case, I know you have it in for me but I don't know why. I have decided to sit at the back of the class from now on to avoid any other conflicts, unless you come looking for them. I admit I can be insolent, but only if I'm provoked. I won't look at you again, so you can't say my look is insolent. In theory, in a French class, you talk about French, not your grandma, your sister or girls' periods. And so, from now on, I won't speak to you again. Signed Khoumba. INT. CLASS —- DAY Khoumba’s voice continues over this next scene. While Frangois is at his desk, the students work on their self- portraits with more or less care. Some have “The Diary of Anne Frank” open on their desks. Others daydream or chat in low voices. On the blackboard, we can read, “I work on my self-portrait”. Frangois goes from table to table, advising the different students.
Why are you hiding it like that? What's wrong?
It's a secret.
A secret? It won't stay a secret for long. Esmeralda, why have you changed places?
No reason, I just wanted to.
Is there a problem?  47.
No, not at all. No problem. I just wanted a change of scene. He turns to Khoumba who immediately looks away.
Okay, that's enough. Let's get to work.
No, sir, please! Please, sir!
You're just copying what you did at home. You've had plenty of time.
That's right, that’s right but, sir, we have to do it neatly here. Please!
Esmeralda, we're listening.
Huh? I have to?
Yes, absolutely.

My name is Esmeralda Ouertani, I'm 14 and I live at 9, Allée du Pére Julien Dhuit, Paris 20, with my two parents and my three brothers and sisters. Later, I'd like to be a policewoman because people say all policemen are bad and so we need good ones. If not, I'd like to be a rapper and I'ma fan of Bakar, Médine, Younes, Marvin and Mafiak'l Fry. Otherwise, I like eating, sleeping and hanging out in the ‘hood.
Yes, or rather?
The neighborhood.
Yes, so why don't you change it since you know how? When you write, you use the standard style. Don't wait until I correct you. Wey, go on.  48.

All right. My name's Wey, I'm Chinese, I'm 15, I have two sisters, I'm the youngest. My hobby is playing video games, at least 4 hours a day. I find it hard using French correctly. It's so hard expressing myself that others don't understand me. That's why I don't communicate much. I hardly ever go out. Nothing much interests me outside. The environment doesn't suit me here since I'm allergic but I don't know what.
Allergic to yourself, that's why they can't find what you're allergic to!
That's good, Wey. I feel that I know you better after hearing your self-portrait. That's the goal. To tell us things.
It just happens to be good when it’s him.
What?
His just happens to be good, not ours. Ours never are.
No, not at all. If Wey's work is good, I congratulate him. And I'll gladly congratulate you if you've managed to do it well. That's the truth... In fact, Rabah, you can read us your self- portrait.
No, I’m not reading.
So how can I congratulate you if you don't?
I don't need that.
Well make your mind up!  49.
You want compliments.
Go on, we're listening.

My name's Rabah, I'm 14, I listen to rap. I love my village in Kabylia and go there every year. I like music, rap and slam. I have two brothers but I don't like school. I don't like tramps. I like Zidane, I like to talk and I like Psy 4 de la Rime's videos. Go Marseille!
We can manage without Marseille.
Go Paris, you mean!
We don't really need it in a self- portrait.
Sir, he didn't read it all! He skipped two lines!
That's all! I read the lot!
Hey, cut it out!
Go, dude!
Boubacar!
"I like to make love".
I never wrote that!
"I like to look good for the women and I like summer to see girls' cleavage."  50.
Okay, all right. (reactions from the other students) Why not, Rabah, why not?
I never wrote that! I won't say who did.
It looks a lot like your writing though.
My writing? No way.
It does. But there's no shame in liking cleavage.
Is this my writing? Frangois looks around the class. His gaze settles on Souleymane.
It's not a sin. Souleymane, stop rocking and read your self-portrait. I'm curious to hear it. The adolescent, sprawled on his chair, sits up straight, taking his time.
Huh?
No, not huh.
I didn't write anything, sir.
But I’m sure you did, I saw you writing earlier.
No, I wrote nothing.
You did.
Nothing!  51.
We're listening.
I'm Souleymane. I have nothing to say about me because no one knows me but me. After a moment’s silence, Frangois says ironically.
(calming the jeers of the other students) Okay, okay, enough.. That's good. A bit long maybe. How come you can't make the effort that the others did?
I don't like talking about myself, that's all.
How come the others make the effort and you don't?
Well, if they do, that's their problem. I don't talk about my life, okay.
Really? This leads to a little laughter. Esmeralda can’t stop herself from making fun of Souleymane.
It's not that he doesn't want to, he just can't write, that's all!
What's up, you cop? You want to be a cop and you're talking to me? Goddam cop!
I can live with it.
All right, that’s enough!
Get lost, cop. Arrest guys instead of talking to me. Got your cuffs?
Chill, French guy.  52.
Your breath stinks!
Chill, okay.
Heard of Aquafresh?
Souleymane, Souleymane, there's no need to be offensive.
I can lend you a toothbrush if you want!
Okay, cut it out. Souleymane, you're a lot better at oral insults, you're great at that, but when it comes to writing, nobody's home.
He can't even write his name. Souleymane’s sole reply is to point to a tattoo in Arabic that he has on his neck.
Zip it! What does this say?
Go on then, the same old shit with your Koran. Souleymane becomes indignant.
Shut your mouth. What's wrong with the Koran? I'll spare you my "shit" when you calm down!
Go on, piss us off, that’s from the Koran?
Hey, calm down.
It’s the Koran so shut your mouth!
Stop making this crap up!  53.
I’m not making it up! Frangois comes over and tries to see the tatoo.
What's that tattoo, Souleymane? Why are you showing it to us?
He says it's from the Koran but that’s not for sure!
Shut your mouth!
Hey, hey! What is it? What is that tattoo? Why are you showing it to us?
It's nothing, it’s nothing! Boubacar comes to his rescue.
It means shut your mouth, shut your mouth!
You shut your mouth! That’s not what it means!
So give us the right translation. Go on, tell us.
I don't want to tell you.
You show it in my class so you're going to tell us what it means. Souleymane hesitates for a second.
It says here, right here: "If your words are less important than silence, keep quiet."
That’s what I said!  54.
No, that’s not what you said.
Hey, Rabah, isn’t that what I said?
No, it’s not what you said.
Why isn't it the same thing that Boubacar said?
I don't know. It's different. I think it sounds better.
Yes, it's better put. Souleymane, if only you could write as interesting things on paper as on your arm, that would be great.
Yeah, yeah, I think so too.

That proves you can do it. Right, after these first few self-portraits, I'd like you to rewrite them and polish them, making sure you answer the questions that we listed at the start of class: what I like and don't like, my qualities and flaws, who I'd like to be.. (a knock on the door) Come in!
Good morning.
Good morning. The principal has come to introduce a new student, CARL, to the class. On seeing that the students aren’t going to move, the principal sets them straight. They stand reluctantly.
Stand up, please. Good morning. That goes for those at the back too. Come on, stand up. Chérif, did you hear me? Everyone has to stand. It's simply a way of greeting an adult. (MORE)

It doesn't mean submission or humiliation. All right. Sit back down. I've come to introduce a new student. Carl. Try to make him welcome until the end of the year. Thank you. Goodbye. Frangois gestures to the classroom. As the principal goes back out, the new students sluggishly takes his place as the other students look on, intrigued.

Thank you. Goodbye. Carl, go sit in the third row, in that free place. Khoumba, can you move your things? Take a sheet of paper and a pen and try to catch up with the others. We'll talk after. (the bell rings) Don't forget the homework for Monday without fail. Let's finish with this. Goodbye. Carl, stay here a minute or two.
Goodbye. Adios, sefior. INT. CLASS —- DAY As the other students leave the classroom, Frangois signals to Carl to wait. The boy looks a little worried.
Welcome.
Thank you. Now that the other students have left, Frangois adopts a more confidential tone.

I don't know if you know but I'm Mr. Marin, your French teacher and your class supervisor. So if there's a problem, you talk to me about it. I know who you are. I mean, I know why you're here. The principal told me but that doesn't matter. We'll start from scratch here, okay? It will all go well. You've seen that we.. We're on self-portraits to be handed in next Monday. Maybe you could do one too. You know when the next class is? Carl looks awkward.  56.
Monday, at 9.30.
Yes, Monday, at 9.30, very good. All right.. And do you like French?
Yes, like everyone, I guess.
That doesn't mean much. Okay, off you go.
Goodbye.
Goodbye. You know what a self-portrait is, that’s not a problem?
Yes.
You're sure?
Yes, have a good day.

One evening after the day’s classes, Frangois, sitting at his desk, sees the students’ parents one by one. We see a series of portraits of the students’ parents. Some defend their offspring tooth and nail, others demand greater severity with their children and others still seem totally indifferent to what Frangois has to say. WEY’S PARENTS seem to be concentrating hard and hanging on Frangois’ every word but the looks on their faces show that they don’t understand.
Good evening. Pleased to meet you. WEY’S FATHER Good evening.
Sit down, please. Thank you for coming. I know it isn't easy. Well, we're very pleased with Wey. Very pleased indeed. (MORE)

FRANgGOIS (CONT'D) All the teachers at the staff meeting said so. He's kind, he's pleasant... It's good to have him in class. And it's showing in his grades. We have.. the usual good grades in mathematics. He's doing well there. 13/20. In French, we have a 9 here... WEY’S FATHER Not a lot. Meanwhile, Wey’s mother looks on, a big smile on her face. She clearly doesn’t understand what is being said but has a vague impression that Frangois is speaking favorably about her son.

Well, he doesn't speak French very well yet but that's only normal. He talks a lot. He tells me about a lot of things. He talks about his computer. He's into that. WEY’S FATHER Yes, yes, always too late.
You think he works too late? WEY’S FATHER Yes, too late, not sleep good. After, school not good. Eyes get sick after.
Yes, his eyes.. In any case, he may spend a lot of time on the computer but things are fine at school for now. WEY’S FATHER Yes, thank you.
He works well and he doesn't seem tired. WEY’S FATHER Thank you. Nassim comes next, with his FATHER
Nassim.. I'd like him to do.. He can go far. He has all he needs. At his age, I wasn't that lucky. I'm right behind him. Anything he needs, I get him, no problem. (MORE)

NASSIM’S FATHER (CONT'D) But he has to do right. It's true, things are good at home with him but I'd like him to keep on studying.. and go far. Me and his mother, we'd like to be proud of him. That's what we ask of him.
I think we all agree on what we need to do. It's crazy how alike you are.
We're lookers in the family, only natural.
Yes, you're right. The next parent is ARTHUR’S MOTHER.

So an adolescent who talks with his family, who has good grades, who has friends, even if he's a bit of a loner, he's an outcast? He's a boy who talks with adults, who exchanges with them. Maybe he doesn't with you but that means he's just a teenager trying to define himself, that's all. I was useless at school for years. I rejected the idea of making us fit in with the system. Do his black clothes bother you? The way he looks? I don't get it. Then comes Burak’s mother (seen at a meeting earlier), with her son. BURAK’S MOTHER I'd like him to go to the best, to Henri Iv.
Henri IV? Why do you want him to go there? BURAK’S MOTHER Because...
Standards again.. Henri IV is all she thinks about. BURAK’S MOTHER Because they have very high standards. A mother always wants the best for her son.  59.

Yeah, my mother's scared I'll feel lost in high school because the others went to fancy private schools and Dolto High isn't as demanding so... BURAK’S MOTHER It's a pity that the teachers, well, maybe not the teachers, I don't want to accuse anyone... but the school...
Go on, accuse us. It's always a pleasure. BURAK’S MOTHER Why don't you try to push the better students a little harder, say? They get bogged down by other students who aren't as good.

My mom makes stuff up. Dolto High isn't useless. She thinks private schools... BURAK’S MOTHER I didn't say useless, I said average. I didn't call it useless. This stream of parents ends with Souleymane’s mother, accompanied by her older son, aged 17 or so. He is the one who speaks since his mother doesn’t understand a word of French.

We talked about Souleymane a great deal at the staff meeting. Many teachers have complained about his attitude, which is very negative. Souleymane’s brother immediately becomes heated. SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER Oh yeah?
Many complain that he comes without his things. When he comes, that is, as he's often absent. He's often late too. SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER Oh yeah?

In any case, I think you know that.  60. SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER No, we didn't know. Souleymane tells us he works hard. A brief conversation with his mother in Malian. Souleymane’s brother becomes annoyed as he translates for his mother who also starts to get angry.
Can you translate for me? SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER She.. she doesn’t believe it.
There have been notes in his report book since September, three months now. Notes about the problems he was having. SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER She signs them without knowing because she can't read, see.
What about you? Do you read the notes too? SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER Yes, but I'm just his brother. You see?
Okay, but you knew there was a problem? SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER No, I didn't know. Whenever I ask, he says things are fine.
Do you see him work at home? SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER He stays in his room Sso..

I see. Another conversation in Malian. Souleymane’s mother, as angry as before, starts talking curtly to her son. Frangois looks at them in surprise. SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER She says she doesn't understand the notes in the report book.  61.

Yes, I realize that. In any case, you know the situation now. I'm telling you officially: there's a problem. You need to talk to him. SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER Yes, I'll talk to him about it, I'll talk to him about it.
Well, just having a.. Maybe a conversation with his father could help too.. it would be interesting. SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER Yes, yes, I'll see, I'll talk to my father and see what we can do tonight.
Okay, we're not settling scores. We just want to improve things. He stands to say goodbye, shaking hands with Souleymane’s mother, then with his brother. SOULEYMANE’S BROTHER Goodbye.
Goodbye. Another conversation in Malian. Souleymane’s mother has already turned to leave.

The students wait in the corridor outside the computer room. Souleymane is showing the others some photos on his cell phone. We see views of his apartment and of him clowning around with his friends. His classmates are impressed by the quality of the photos but start laughing when they see a photo of Souleymane’s mother, particularly tense and glum in front of the camera.
Is that your mom?
You bet.
Shit, she’s an ugly old crow!  62.
Shut your mouth, your ma's ugly, and so are you.
She sulking or what?

Did you... (she greets someone who passes) Did you call them skanks?
Yes, but Souleymane's another matter!  93.
I know it had nothing to do with him. But word's getting around. People are talking. I wanted to let you know.
Well, thanks for letting me know. Frangois has spoken absently because, out of the window, he has just spotted Esmeralda in the yard.
Frangois hurries across the yard towards Esmeralda as if he were ready for a fight.
Hey, you two. You complained about me to the year supervisor. Thanks a lot! They step away from the other students. Esmeralda, caught off guard, stammers a little.
You're welcome.
You could have talked to me about it, couldn’t you? Louise comes over to her friend and joins the conversation.
When a teacher complains about us, he sees the year supervisor, we can do the same thing, right?
No, it doesn't work both ways. He has raised his voice. A group has formed around them. We notice that Khoumba has a dressing over her eyebrow.
Of course it’s the same. Of course it is.
Absolutely not. What were you after by doing this?
We wanted to see you punished like us!  94.
To see me punished...
Yes.
You're going to get me punished?
Yes, you insulted us, you get punished!
And where will that get you, me being punished?
At least I'll have spoken out.
Great, that's a lot of use.
I mean, do you even know what "skank" means?
That's not the problem because I never called you skanks!
Yes, you did, you called us skanks. For me, skank means prostitute.
Not at all.
It does.
For me, it doesn't mean that. It's nothing important at all, just a girl laughing stupidly. It’s no worse than that. Esmeralda turns to the circle of girls around her.
Hey, skank means prostitute, right?
You bet!  95.
Will Souleymane get expelled? Frangois is caught off his guard. Carl butts
Of course not.. but...
Will he get a disciplinary hearing?
We don't know yet. It's a possibility. Stop yelling before anything's decided.
It's all settled anyway. We know that!
It isn’t. Why do you say that?
Because. It’s always the same.
I’s always the same!
You know, you're in no position to talk. You're the one who got hurt during the incident.
So? He didn't mean it. There was a metal thing in his bag.
Whatever happened, he blew a fuse and that's bad. in.
Sir, anyone can blow a fuse.
Yes, they can, but they can calm down after too!
That’s not so sure.
You calmed down, right?  96.
No.
You're a lot calmer since you got here.
No, I haven’t calmed down. You don’t know me better than I know myself!
All the teachers say your attitude is perfect now. So don't try to pretend otherwise.
So what's the idea? You think you've tamed me?
No, it doesn't mean we've tamed you. But being sent here by a disciplinary committee helped you understand things, see?
It didn't help me. I don't understand your shit!
In making that decision about you, maybe your old teachers wanted to help you and we'll do the same for Souleymane.
Sorry, but I say teachers who expel students are fuckers.
Right on!
Bravo, you want to repeat that?
Yeah, they’re fuckers.
This is incredible. Everyone goes wild over some word I said. You say fucker and I shouldn't react?
I don’t give a damn, they’re fuckers!  97.
Cut it out!
Hey! You say skanks, we say fucker. You may not like it but it's the same. It's the same!
First of all, the two words are nothing alike! And if you can't understand that a teacher can say certain things that students can't say, well.. We'll never get anywhere!
We're not allowed to say nothing. We're not allowed to say nothing!
Rubbish! You keep talking all the time! You never stop speaking!
Whenever we talk, you yell. What is this?
Enough! Frangois, at a loose end, leaves the group.
As he enters the canteen hallway, Khoumba catches up with him. She is alone and looks worried.
Sir! Sir!
What?
Tell me, will Souleymane get a hearing or not? Frangois, surprised by the emotion in Khoumba’s voice, turns to look at her.
Give it a rest! You sound like you want him to. It fires you up.  98.
Do you know what'll happen if he's expelled?
He'll change schools.
No, he won't change schools.
He will, it's automatic. It's obligatory. That goes for Souleymane too.
Do you know his father?
I've seen him once or twice.
No, you don’t know him! If Souleymane is expelled, his dad'll send him back to their village!
Don't get overdramatic.
He'll go back to Mali!
I think we all need to keep our heads here. It's okay, don't worry. He walks away.

Frangois comes into the deserted canteen. There are trays on the tables, the leftovers of lunch. He sits down ina He looks a little lost. We find him a little later smoking a cigarette as two WOMEN clear the trays away at the other end of the room, putting them on a trolley. On reaching him, one of them points to Frangois’ cigarette.
You can't smoke here, sir.
Yes, I know, but since I was alone...  99.
The rules hold for everyone. Frangois puts out his cigarette in a dirty plate. The woman takes the tray, glaring at him.
Frangois is with the other teachers, talking about Souleymane. Frédéric speaks up.
Okay, you went too far with those girls. But we all screw up. It doesn't excuse what Souleymane did.
Listen, Frangois, he's right. I saw Khoumba. Her face was all bloody. What he did is unacceptable.
That’s for sure.
That's another thing, her bloody face... His bag hit her by accident. A split eyebrow bleeds a lot. That's all.
You can’t ignore it!
Come on, Frangois, don't take it to heart. You've seen how they talk to us?
How's that relevant? Souleymane is going to get a disciplinary hearing and he'll be expelled.
That's kind of logical.
So let's talk about that. How many hearings were there last year? Twelve at least.
Not that many.  100.
Yes, he could be right.
I know, I'm on the committee so I saw them all. An average of two a month, twelve in all, with an expulsion each time.
Come on, the hearing is where we talk things over. Okay, so twelve students were expelled but maybe there was no other solution.
Twelve out of twelve means there wasn't much of a discussion unfortunately!
But twelve out of twelve just means... when a student has a hearing, it's too late.
Or that it was justified.
Okay, things happen that lead to a hearing. But then what happens? What do we expect from a hearing?
There are all the prior stages. You know that, Frangois. The pre-disciplinary committees, we inform the parents, the students are warned...
Not in this case.
We've no time to.
It’s pretty rare.

It's rare because we know we have this ultimate punishment that allows us to ignore the prior steps. And even if we did use them, the simple fact of expelling a student.. I don't know, it's a disavowal of everything we have tried.  101.
Okay, but at the same time it's Souleymane's chance to justify himself.
Sure! Students at hearings don't speak. They're scared. They're paralyzed. Frangois then decides to use what Khoumba told him.
Exactly. Let me sum this up. He'll get a disciplinary hearing, he'll be expelled and maybe even sent back to Mali.
You're being overdramatic.
No, I'm not. Students who know him better than any of us here, who know his father, say that he is likely to send him back to Mali after this.
Some kids are threatened with boarding school but it never happens!
It can happen!
Come on, a lot of parents spend their time threatening their kids with that. But you can't take it into account.
Even if there’s just a slight risk that a hearing could lead to him being sent back, I don't think I can take that risk. That's all.

It's like when you hesitate over punishing a kid because when he goes home, once that door closes, he'll get a beating from his parents. We've all seen that. But we still have to punish them when they go too far. Whatever the consequences, which don't concern you.  102.
So I ignore that? I know punishment can have such a consequence but I turn a blind eye, I don't want to know, is that it?
No, but I understand...
Hold on a second. You can't take it into account in every case or you won't get anywhere. The violence, him being sent back... True, you have to consider it but after a while...
No more Christmas presents.. It happens, yes.
Afterwards, it's a question of principle. We each have a role to play. We can't substitute ourselves for the parents.

Sorry, but if I rewind the movie, it's a weird chain of events. It starts with reprimands when Souleymane starts screwing up, forgets his things, or talks back. We punish him. Again and again, until a disciplinary hearing leading to who knows what. Little by little, everything gets out of hand.
Sure, if you look at it that way, it's really shocking. But, once again, the school won't be expelling Souleymane. He's been gone for a while.
Frangois leaves the staff room. He walks along the corridor, thinking.
The students start to form into their classes as they continue to horse about in the yard.  103.
Frangois knocks on the door and comes in. The principal doesn’t seem to be very surprised to see him.
Frangois... I didn't expect you so soon. Have you reached a decision?
Well, I don't think I really have much choice. He sits down a little heavily on the chair facing the principal. He doesn't say a word. The principal goes on in a kindly voice.
By the way, Julie told me you had a heated exchange with two girls in your class.
Yes, the two class reps but it happened first so..
You apparently called them "skanks".
Let's say that, yes.

Well, that complicates things but the problem remains. I'd like you to mention it in your report. I don't want it used against us at the disciplinary hearing. Don't bother hiding it, just write it down.
I understand.
I'll let you go back over this before we launch the procedure.
So I.. I just need to add the...
Yes, yes, but without going into detail. Does that suit you.  104. Frangois shows no reaction.
Okay.
Frangois, alone in the staff room again, rewrites his incident report.
The tables have been set out in a U-shape in the meeting room. The people come in. PARENTS’ REPS Hello. Hello, sir.

Please sit down. Souleymane and his mother sit on one side, with the two student representatives. The teaching staff sits on another side and the parents’ representatives on the third side of the U. Frangois remains silent and tries in vain to catch Souleymane’s eye. The boy, stubborn, stares at the principal who leads the debate, sitting between Julie, the class supervisor, and the bursar, Monsieur Pierre.
(to Julie) Can you take the minutes? We fast-forward to the heart of the meeting as the principal reads from Frangois’ report.

"Carl tried to reason with him and stop him. Souleymane broke free, swinging his bag that hit Khoumba in the face. Then he left, insulting everyone and slamming the door. I didn't go after him because I needed to help Khoumba whose eyebrow was bleeding." Those are the facts that led to today's hearing. Madame, it doesn't mean Souleymane is a bad boy. That's not what we're saying. (MORE)

But, sometimes, a student in a class, through voluntary or involuntary behavior, can create an atmosphere that prevents the class from working and getting ahead. (Souleymane translates) Do you understand what we're saying?

If I may say something, it's true that there had been a number of signs that should have warned us. We could have reacted sooner. But now we have to deal with an incident that is fairly violent and that's simply unacceptable. I'd like to know if you realize that, Souleymane?
You see, we're not saying you're deliberately violent. The problem is you can't control what you say and what you do.
Souleymane, we'd like to hear you. You're here to express your point of view. Go ahead.

I don't give a damn. I've got nothing to say. Do whatever you want to do. His mother says something in Malian. She seems to be telling him off for his aggressive reaction to the teachers’ accusations.
Excuse Mme... Souleymane’s mother continues to speak in Malian.
Can you translate?
She says I'm a good boy. I do my homework. I help my brothers and sisters with their work when I can. I always wash the dishes and help her when I can.

Madam, we don't doubt that Souleymane is a good son. That's not the problem. I'd like to get back to his school record.  106. PARENTS’ REP #1 Excuse me, but could we focus on the facts here? It's odd to be both judge and litigant.

First of all, Mr. Marin was elected to the administrative board as the teachers' representative. I did say that but it wasn't something that concerned Souleymane. I think he used the excuse of a rather heated exchange with those two students to express the bad mood he was in that day. PARENTS’ REP #1 He tried to defend them. So I feel that it's relevant. Frangois, awkward, prefers not to reply while Frédéric, annoyed, answers for him.
I'm sorry, but absolutely nothing justifies being disrespectful to a teacher, insulting everyone and leaving a class without permission.
Souleymane, do you have anything to say?
I don't know. What can I say?  107. SOULEYMANE’S MOTHER Sir, madame... She then continues in Malian.
Souleymane?
What did your mother say?
The same thing as before. His mother says something else in Malian.
Yes, Souleymane?
She apologizes on my behalf.
Souleymane and his mother sit down on a bench in the corridor. They don’t speak or even look at each other.
In the meeting room, the vote is under way. Everyone taking part in the meeting drops a small piece of paper into a box that is passed around. Everyone is silent.
The year supervisor comes to fetch Souleymane and his mother who are still in the same position.
You can come back in now. They stand and follow her into the room. As soon as they sit down, the principal starts speaking.

Madame, the committee has conferred and has decided to expel Souleymane from the school for good. You will receive the ruling by registered mail and have eight days to appeal. Souleymane too stands and goes out with looking back as the principal continues to address him.
Souleymane, come to see me before the end of the week, please.

Souleymane and his mother cross the yard to the exit. From the window, Frangois watches them go. INT. CLASS —- DAY For the students’ final class, the atmosphere is relaxed. We can sense that the tension of the year has eased. The students are like actors after a show. Frangois invites the students to weigh up the past year: what they have learned, what they particularly liked.
Mathematical proportionality.
This year, you learned mathematical proportionality. All right.
I liked science.
What you learned, not what you liked. If you liked it, you learned. So what did you learn in science?
All about volcanoes, earthquakes, plates... Convergence and divergence, movement of the Earth's plates... It was fascinating.
It interested you?
Yeah.  109.
That's good.
Well, in mathematics, trigonometry, Pythagoras' theorem, Thalés' theorem...
I'll stop you there. You can't sit there and brag you learned Pythagoras' theorem. Recite it for us.
If, in a triangle.. two sides are equal to.. If the square root.. If the square of two sides is equal to the square... the square of the hypotenuse... then the triangle's a right-angled triangle.
More or less, yes.
It's spot on.
All right. If you say so, I believe you.

In history, I learned about triangular trade. The fact that ships left Europe with manufactured goods that they took to Africa to trade for men who'd become slaves that they took to America to work. Then they took the money they made back to Europe. That's triangular trade.
Chemistry.
What in chemistry?
Combustion.
Okay and what's that?
Blending Fehling's solution and glucose.
What do you get?  110.
Heat up the test-tube and it changes color.
What's the interest in knowing that?
The interest in knowing that? I dunno. Why teach it to us if there's no interest?
Reproduction.
What did you learn about human reproduction, for instance?
Human reproduction... Well, the sperm gets into the ovum, then you wait 9 months, then you do a sonogram and then it comes out.
The sperm does?
No, the human being that's inside.
Khoumba?
Me?
Yes. That is your name?
Yes. In music, I learned to play the alto recorder... and in Spanish.
You learned to play the recorder in Spanish?
No, in music, I learned to play the alto recorder. And I learned other stuff in Spanish.  111.
Very good. Can you say something to us in Spanish?
Llegan las vacaciones.
And that means?
It's the vacation soon or the vacation's coming.
I didn't learn anything.
You can't spend 9 months at school and not learn anything.
You can, I'm the living proof.
You got something from the books we read.
Your books are shite.
They're what?
They're useless.
What about a book you read by yourself?
A book I read? Well, there's "The Republic". The book "The Republic".
“The Republic” by Plato?
Yeah.
You read that? How come you read that?
My big sister had it.  112.
She does philosophy?
No, law.
So what's it about?
Well, there's this guy...
Socrates, his name's Socrates.

Yeah, Socrates. This guy, he stops people in the street and he asks them: "Are you sure of thinking what you think? Are you sure of doing what you do?" And so on. After that, people start getting confused. They ask questions. The guy's too much.
What does he ask people about?
Everything. Love, religion, God, people, everything.
It's good you read it.
I know. She hesitates, then adopts a mischievous tone.

It's not a skank's book! This remark elicits laughter from the students who were starting to get bored with this discussion about Socrates. There’s an air of reconciliation in the air. The ringing of the bell creates a mood of general euphoria that Frangois calms down.

Wait a second! Before you leave, here are your self-portraits. One by one. When you have yours, you can go. Each one of you in turn.  113. As an end-of-year gift, he hands out the book of self- portraits that he has had bound. The students are over the moon as they look for their own texts. A moment of intense pride. Khoumba leafs through the pages of Souleymane’s photos in silence.
Sir, this is really kind of you.
What is it?
These are the self-portraits that you wrote and that we made up with the class photo and so on. (to a student) You don't have yours?
Sir, seriously, why did you put this here?
You look good in it.
Cut it out!
You're like a leader. Have a good vacation.
Thank you. You too. The students hurry out. For the first time, Henriette dares to approach her teacher.
Sir? Frangois looks surprised.
Yes? What is it?
I didn't learn anything.
What? Why are you saying that? That doesn't mean anything.  114. The girl is edgy, on the verge of tears.
Earlier, all the others said they'd learned something. Compared to them, I learned nothing.
Come on, you learned as much as them. They had to think hard too. It's not easy to remember what you learned off the top of your head like that.
But I don't understand.
What do you mean?
I don't understand what we do.
In French?
In everything.
You can't say you don't understand anything in any subject. That's not true, it’s...
I don't want to go to vocational school.

There's no question of that yet. You're moving on to the next year. You'll have plenty of time to think about your future. Vocational school isn't an absolute certainty. It all depends on how you do next year. With what she hopes is a discreet gesture, she dries her tears.
But I don't want to. She goes out, leaving Frangois alone and a little sad.  115.
In the yard, we find the students, teachers and members of the administrative staff caught up in a soccer match. The adolescents are virtually hysterical at the idea of tackling their teachers.
(shouting during the game) Go! All together! All together!
